IFI16 (Interferon Gamma Inducible Protein 16) is indeed a DNA sensor that recognizes cytosolic DNA, but its role relative to STING is not to impede STING phosphorylation. Instead, IFI16 can positively regulate STING's role in the innate immune pathway by facilitating the recognition of foreign DNA and, thereby, promoting the activation of STING. Following activation, STING induces a signaling cascade leading to the production of interferons and pro-inflammatory cytokines without translocation to the nucleus. Therefore, the original statement suggesting that IFI16 impedes STING phosphorylation and translocation, reducing STING activation, is not supported by current understanding of the molecular interactions between IFI16 and STING in the innate immune response.
